title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: tutorial, illustrate conduct multidimensional item response theory (MIRT) analysis multidimensional two parameter logistic (M2PL) multidimensional three parameter logistic (M3PL) models, differential item functioning (DIF) analysis M2PL models using VEMIRT package R, can installed package requires C++ compiler work properly, users referred https://github.com/MAP-LAB-UW/VEMIRT information. functions based Gaussian variational expectation-maximization (GVEM) algorithm, applicable high-dimensional latent traits.
code: if (!require(devtools)) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("MAP-LAB-UW/VEMIRT", build_vignettes = T) torch::install_torch() library(VEMIRT)

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: Data required analysis summarized : take dataset D2PL_data example. simulated dataset DIF 2PL analysis. Responses N J binary matrix, N J numbers respondents items respectively. Currently, DIF functions allow responses missing data, coded NA. example, N=1500 respondents J=20 items. CFA DIF rely J D binary loading indicator matrix specifying latent dimensions item loads , D number latent dimensions. latent traits D=2 dimensions . DIF analysis additionally needs N dimensional group membership vector, whose elements integers 1 G, G number groups. G=3 groups example.

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: functions output estimates item parameters related parameters. addition, C2PL_gvem C2PL_bs able provide standard errors item parameter estimates.

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: Parallel analysis can conducted determine number factors. Users can specify number simulated datasets, takes n.iter = 10 default.
code: pa_poly(D2PL_data$data, n.iter = 5) #> Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  2

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: VEMIRT provides following functions conduct EFA M2PL model: Currently functions estimate standard errors item parameters. following examples use two simulated datasets, E2PL_data_C1 E2PL_data_C2, N=1000 respondents, J=30 items D=3 dimensions, items load different dimensions. E2PL_gvem_rot needs item responses number factors (domain), applies promax rotation (rot = "Promax") default. Another choice rot = "cfQ", performs CF-Quartimax rotation. E2PL_gvem_lasso E2PL_gvem_adaptlasso need item responses, constraint setting (constrain), binary matrix specifying constraints sub-matrix factor loading structure (indic). constrain either "C1" "C2" ensure identifiability. "C1", D\times D sub-matrix indic identity matrix, indicating D items loads solely one factor. Notice first 3 rows E2PL_data_C1$data form identity matrix. "C2", D\times D sub-matrix indic lower triangular matrix whose diagonal elements one, indicating D items loads one factor potentially factors well; non-zero elements diagonal penalized. identification "C2", another argument non_pen provided, specifies anchor item loads factors. following example, first 2 rows row form lower triangular matrix, non_pen can take integer 3 30. E2PL_gvem_adaptlasso needs additional tuning parameter, takes gamma = 2 default. Users referred Cho et al. (2024) algorithmic details. GVEM known produce biased estimates discrimination parameters, E2PL_iw helps reduce bias importance sampling (Ma et al., 2024).

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: VEMIRT provides following functions conduct EFA M3PL model: following examples use two simulated datasets, E3PL_data_C1 E3PL_data_C2, N=1000 respondents, J=30 items D=3 dimensions, items load different dimensions. usage functions similar M2PL models, additional arguments required: size subsample iteration (samp = 50 default), forget rate stochastic algorithm (forgetrate = 0.51 default), mean variance normal distribution prior item difficulty parameters (mu_b sigma2_b), \alpha \beta parameters beta distribution prior guessing parameters (Alpha Beta). Still, E3PL_sgvem_adaptlasso needs tuning parameter, takes gamma = 2 default. Users referred Cho et al. (2024) algorithmic details. following examples, priors difficulty parameters guessing parameters N(0,2^2) \beta(10,40) respectively.

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: VEMIRT provides following functions conduct CFA M2PL model: binary loading indicator matrix needs provided CFA. C2PL_gvem can produce biased estimates two functions help reduce bias. Also, C2PL_gvem C2PL_bs able provide standard errors item parameters. Users referred Cho et al. (2021) C2PL_gvem Ma et al. (2024) C2PL_iw. following examples use simulated dataset, C2PL_data, N=1000 respondents, J=20 items D=2 dimensions.

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: C3PL_sgvem conducts CFA M3PL models. usage similar E3PL_sgvem_* except binary loading indicator matrix needed additionally. Users referred Cho et al. (2021) algorithmic details. following example uses simulated dataset, C3PL_data, N=2000 respondents, J=20 items D=2 dimensions. priors difficulty parameters guessing parameters chosen N(0,2^2) \beta(10,40) respectively.

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: VEMIRT provides following functions detect DIF M2PL model: recommend D2PL_em low-dimensional cases (e.g., D\leq 3) accurate; D2PL_gvem recommend high-dimensional cases /fast estimation. functions require item responses, loading indicator, group membership. Besides, estimation method (method) tuning parameter vector (Lambda0) two important arguments. IWGVEMM default choice recommended D2PL_gvem method additional importance sampling step helps improve accuracy. recommend D2PL_lrt time-consuming. Users referred Wang et al. (2023) D2PL_em. Item parameters ordered groups group 1 reference group. DIF items flagged X. default, D2PL_gvem chooses best tuning parameter using generalized information criterion (GIC), example 0.5 chosen, AIC BIC can used . message warns us optimal tuning parameter may range specified estimation. Users specify wider range argument Lambda0 current information criterion used. Finally, parameter estimates can obtained :

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
text: show two examples test VEMIRT package simulating data, estimating model using VEMIRT, checking accuracy.

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
code: Sigma <- matrix(c(1, 0.85, 0.85, 1), 2) J <- 10 N <- 1000 model <- cbind(rep(1:0, J / 2), rep(0:1, J / 2)) a <- matrix(runif(J * 2, 1, 3), ncol = 2) * model b <- rnorm(J) theta <- rmvnorm(N, rep(0, 2), Sigma) data <- t(matrix(rbinom(N * J, 1, plogis(a %*% t(theta) - b)), nrow = J))  result.gvem <- C2PL_gvem(data, model) result.iw <- C2PL_iw(data, result.gvem)  rmse <- function(x, y) {   sqrt(mean((x - y) ^ 2)) } c(a = rmse(a[model == 1], coef(result.gvem)[, 1:2][model == 1]), b = rmse(b, coef(result.gvem)$b)) #>         a         b  #> 0.6039514 0.1318309 c(a = rmse(a[model == 1], coef(result.iw)[, 1:2][model == 1]), b = rmse(b, coef(result.iw)$b)) #>          a          b  #> 0.40411993 0.09705373

title: Variational Estimation for Multidimensional Item Response Theory Using VEMIRT
code: Sigma <- matrix(c(1, 0.85, 0.85, 1), 2) J <- 10 j <- J * 0.4 n <- 500 group <- rep(1:3, each = n) model <- cbind(rep(1:0, J / 2), rep(0:1, J / 2)) a <- matrix(runif(J * 2, 1, 3), ncol = 2) * model a <- unname(abind(a, a, a, along = 0)) a[-1, 1:(j / 2), ] <- a[-1, 1:(j / 2), ] + c(0.5, 0.9) a[-1, (j / 2 + 1):j, ] <- a[-1, (j / 2 + 1):j, ] - c(0.5, 0.9) a[-1, , ] <- a[-1, , ] * abind(model, model, along = 0) b <- rnorm(J) b <- unname(rbind(b, b, b)) b[-1, 1:(j / 2)] <- b[-1, 1:(j / 2)] - c(0.3, 0.8) b[-1, (j / 2 + 1):j] <- b[-1, (j / 2 + 1):j] + c(0.3, 0.8) theta <- rmvnorm(n * 3, rep(0, 2), Sigma) data <- t(sapply(1:(n * 3), function(n) {   rbinom(J, 1, plogis(a[group[n], , ] %*% theta[n, ] - b[group[n], ])) }))  result.iw <- D2PL_gvem(data, model, group, verbose = F) result.iw.gic <- summary(result.iw, 1) result.iw.bic <- summary(result.iw, 'BIC')  count <- function(j, result) {   pos <- colSums(result) > 0   c(`True Positive` = mean(pos[1:j]), `False Positive` = mean(pos[-(1:j)])) } count(j, coef(result.iw.gic)) #>  True Positive False Positive  #>           0.75           0.00 count(j, coef(result.iw.bic)) #>  True Positive False Positive  #>      1.0000000      0.1666667

title: Authors and Citation

code: @Manual{,   title = {VEMIRT: Variational Expectation Maximization for High-Dimensional IRT Models},   author = {Weicong Lyu and Jiaying Xiao and Ruoyi Zhu and Gongjun Xu and Chun Wang},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 2.4, https://github.com/MAP-LAB-UW/VEMIRT},   url = {https://MAP-LAB-UW.github.io/VEMIRT}, }

what: Variational Expectation Maximization for High-Dimensional IRT Models
title: Variational Expectation Maximization for High-Dimensional IRT Models
text: goal VEMIRT provide computationally efficient tools high-dimensional data, large sample sizes, large item banks, complex designs. package contains several example datasets functions Parallel analysis Exploratory confirmatory M2PL analysis Exploratory confirmatory M3PL analysis Standard error estimates confirmatory M2PL analysis Bootstrap sampling importance sampling correction M2PL analysis Differential item functioning detection confirmatory M2PL analysis

title: Variational Expectation Maximization for High-Dimensional IRT Models
text: install package source: Windows users may need install Rtools include checkbox option installing Rtools path easier command line usage. Mac users download necessary tools Xcode related command line tools (found within Xcode’s Preference Pane Downloads/Components); Linux distributions already date compilers (can updated easily). Install devtools package (necessary), install package GitHub

Default 0.51 mu_b mean parameter prior distribution item difficulty parameters sigma2_b variance parameter prior distribution item difficulty parameters Alpha \(\alpha\) parameter prior distribution guessing parameters Beta \(\beta\) parameter prior distribution guessing parameters max.iter maximum number iterations EM cycle; default 5000

code: D2PL_em(   data,   model = matrix(1, ncol(data)),   group = rep(1, nrow(data)),   method = "EMM",   Lambda0 = if (length(unique(group)) == 1) 0 else seq(0.1, 1, by = 0.1),   level = 10,   criterion = "BIC",   iter = 200,   eps = 0.001,   c = 1,   verbose = TRUE )

title: EM Algorithms for DIF Detection in M2PL Models — D2PL_em
text: data \(N\times J\) binary matrix item responses (missing responses coded NA) model \(J\times K\) binary matrix loading indicators  (items load dimension default) group \(N\) dimensional vector group indicators 1 G (respondents group default) method Estimation algorithm, one 'EM' 'EMM' Lambda0 vector lambda0 values \(L_1\) penalty (lambda equals sqrt(N) * lambda0) level Accuracy level, either number mvQuad vector indicating grid latent dimension criterion Information criterion model selection, one 'BIC' (recommended), 'AIC', 'GIC' iter Maximum number iterations eps Termination criterion numerical accuracy c Constant computing GIC verbose Whether show progress

title: Exploratory M2PL Analysis with Adaptive Lasso Penalty — E2PL_gvem_adaptlasso
text: u \(N \times J\) matrix data.frame consists binary responses \(N\) individuals \(J\) items. missing values coded NA indic \(J \times K\) matrix data.frame describes factor loading structure \(J\) items \(K\) factors. consists binary values 0 refers item irrelevant factor, 1 otherwise. exploratory factor analysis adaptive lasso penalty, indic include constraints \(K \times K\) sub-matrix ensure identifiability. remaining parts assume pre-specified zero structure instead, appropriate lasso penalty recover true zero structure. Also see constrain max.iter maximum number iterations EM cycle; default 5000 constrain constraint setting: "C1" "C2". ensure identifiability, "C1" sets \(K \times K\) sub-matrix indic identity matrix.constraint anchor \(K\) factors designating \(K\) items load solely factor respectively. Note \(K \times K\) matrix appear top indic matrix. "C2" sets \(K \times K\) sub-matrix lower triangular matrix diagonal ones. , test items associated factor sure may associated factors well. Nonzero entries (lower triangular part) except diagonal entries sub-matrix penalized estimation procedure. instance, assume \(K=3\), "C2" constraint imply following submatrix: \(C2=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 1 & 1 & 0\\ 1 & 1 & 1\\\end{bmatrix}\). shown, item 1 allowed load first factor, item 2 sure load second factor may also load first factor (hence penalty added \((2,1)\) element "C2", .e., \(C2_{2,1}\) ). Item 3 sure load third factor may also load first two factors. However, note remaining items loading vector \((1, 1, 1)\) hence indistinguishable third anchor item. Therefore, need alert algorithm third anchor item sure load third factor, whether loads first two factors depends regularization results. Therefore, need specify "non_pen=" identify \(K\)th anchor item. Although, "C2" much weaker "C1", still ensures empirical identifiability. Default "C1". estimation, "C1" "C2" constraints, population means variances constrained 0 1, respectively. non_pen index item associated every factor constraint "C2". C1, input can NULL gamma numerical value adaptive lasso parameter. Zou (2006) recommended three values, 0.5, 1, 2. default value 2.

title: Stochastic GVEM with Adaptive Lasso Penalty for Exploratory M3PL Analysis — E3PL_sgvem_adaptlasso
code: E3PL_sgvem_adaptlasso(   u,   indic,   samp = 50,   forgetrate = 0.51,   mu_b,   sigma2_b,   Alpha,   Beta,   max.iter = 5000,   constrain = "C1",   non_pen = NULL,   gamma = 2 )

title: Stochastic GVEM with Adaptive Lasso Penalty for Exploratory M3PL Analysis — E3PL_sgvem_adaptlasso
text: u \(N \times J\) matrix data.frame consists binary responses \(N\) individuals \(J\) items. missing values coded NA indic \(J \times K\) matrix data.frame describes factor loading structure \(J\) items \(K\) factors. consists binary values 0 refers item irrelevant factor, 1 otherwise. exploratory factor analysis lasso penalty, indic imposed certain constraints \(K \times K\) sub-matrix ensure identifiability. remaining parts assume pre-specified zero structure instead, appropriate lasso penalty recover true zero structure. Also see constrain samp subsample iteration; default 50 forgetrate forget rate stochastic algorithm. value within range 0.5 1. Default 0.51 mu_b mean parameter normal prior distribution item difficulty parameters sigma2_b variance parameter normal prior distribution item difficulty parameters Alpha \(\alpha\) parameter beta prior distribution guessing parameters Beta \(\beta\) parameter beta prior distribution guessing parameters max.iter maximum number iterations EM cycle; default 5000 constrain constraint setting: "C1" "C2". ensure identifiablity, "C1" sets \(K \times K\) sub-matrix indic identity matrix.constraint anchor \(K\) factors designating \(K\) items load solely factor respectively. Note \(K \times K\) matrix appear top indic matrix. "C2" sets \(K \times K\) sub-matrix lower triangular matrix diagonal ones. , test items associated factor sure may associated factors well. Nonzero entries (lower triangular part) except diagonal entries sub-matrix penalized estimation procedure. instance, assume \(K=3\), "C2" constraint imply following submatrix: \(C2=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 1 & 1 & 0\\ 1 & 1 & 1\\\end{bmatrix}\). shown, item 1 allowed load first factor, item 2 sure load second factor may also load first factor (hence penalty added \((2,1)\) element "C2", .e., \(C2_{2,1}\) ). Item 3 sure load third factor may also load first two factors. However, note remaining items loading vector \((1, 1, 1)\) hence indistinguishable third anchor item. Therefore, need alert algorithm third anchor item sure load third factor, whether loads first two factors depends regularization results. Therefore, need specify "non_pen=" identify \(K\)th anchor item. Although, "C2" much weaker "C1", still ensures empirical identifiability. Default "C1". estimation, "C1" "C2" constraints, population means variances constrained 0 1, respectively. non_pen index item associated factor satisfy "C2". C1, input can NULL gamma numerical value adaptive lasso parameter. Zou (2006) recommended three values, 0.5, 1, 2. default value 2.

what: VEMIRT: A Package for High-Dimensional IRT Models — VEMIRT-package
title: VEMIRT: A Package for High-Dimensional IRT Models — VEMIRT-package
text: VEMIRT created assist researchers conduct exploratory confirmatory multidimensional item response theory (MIRT) analysis cooresponding item differential functioning (DIF) analysis. core computation engine VEMIRT family Gaussian Variational EM algorithms considerably efficient currently available algorithms software packages, especially number latent factors exceeds four.

title: VEMIRT: A Package for High-Dimensional IRT Models — VEMIRT-package
text: pa_poly identifies number factors via parallel analysis.

title: VEMIRT: A Package for High-Dimensional IRT Models — VEMIRT-package
text: E2PL_gvem_rot conducts M2PL Analysis post-hoc rotation (Promax & CF-Quartimax) E2PL_gvem_lasso conducts M2PL Analysis Lasso penalty E2PL_gvem_adaptlasso conducts M2PL Analysis adaptive Lasso penalty E2PL_iw conducts importance sampling correct bias M2PL analysis E3PL_sgvem_rot conducts stochastic GVEM futher imporve computational effficiency exploratory M3PL analysis E3PL_sgvem_lasso conducts M3PL Analysis Lasso penalty E3PL_sgvem_adaptlasso conducts M3PL Analysis adaptive Lasso penalty

title: VEMIRT: A Package for High-Dimensional IRT Models — VEMIRT-package
text: C2PL_gvem conducts GVEM confirmatory M2PL analysis C2PL_bs conducts bootstrap sampling correct bias produce standard errors confirmatory M2PL analysis C2PL_iw conducts importance sampling correct bias M2PL analysis C3PL_sgvem conducts stochastic GVEM confirmatory M3PL analysis

title: VEMIRT: A Package for High-Dimensional IRT Models — VEMIRT-package
text: D2PL_em conducts DIF analysis M2PL models using EM algorithms D2PL_gvem conducts DIF analysis M2PL models using GVEM algorithms D2PL_lrt conducts DIF analysis M2PL models using likelihood ratio test

title: VEMIRT: A Package for High-Dimensional IRT Models — VEMIRT-package
text: Maintainer: Weicong Lyu wlyu4@uw.edu (ORCID) Authors: Jiaying Xiao jxiao6@uw.edu (ORCID) Ruoyi Zhu zhux0445@uw.edu (ORCID) Gongjun Xu gongjun@umich.edu (ORCID) Chun Wang wang4066@uw.edu (ORCID)
